issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to an interface named Rideable (with method messageOnRide()), but the solution repository implements an interface named Mountable (Mountable.messageOnRide()) and leaves Rideable.java empty. Pig and Seal in the solution implement Mountable, while the template/Main and the UML in the problem assume Rideable. This name/type mismatch (and the empty Rideable.java) is a structural inconsistency: students following the problem/template will expect to implement/use Rideable, but the provided solution uses a different interface type, which is confusing and prevents directly using the solution as reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the ride interface name consistent across all artifacts. Preferred fix: rename Mountable to Rideable in the solution (or change Mountable.java to declare 'public interface Rideable { String messageOnRide(); }'), update Pig and Seal to implement Rideable, and remove or populate the empty Rideable.java file so the solution matches the problem/template. Alternatively, change the problem statement and template to use 'Mountable' instead of 'Rideable' if that name was intended — but whichever choice is made, ensure the interface name and file contents are consistent across problem, template, and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to an interface named 'Rideable' (with method messageOnRide()), but the reference solution defines and uses an interface named 'Mountable' instead. In the solution, Pig and Seal implement Mountable, while Rideable.java in the solution repository is empty. This mismatched interface name for the same conceptual entity (animals that can be ridden) breaks the one-to-one mapping between the exercise description/template and the reference implementation and will confuse students (they will look for/implement Rideable as specified in the UML and template but find Mountable in the solution).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the interface name across all artifacts. Prefer changing the solution to match the problem/template: rename Mountable to Rideable (file Mountable.java -> Rideable.java) and ensure it declares String messageOnRide(); update Pig and Seal to implement Rideable. Alternatively, if 'Mountable' is intended, update the problem statement and template to use 'Mountable' consistently. The first option is recommended so the reference solution matches the UML and starter code.
